titleproper.value: Guide to the Ethical Culture Fieldston School Records<lb/>1879-2017<lb/> <num>MS 3042</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-11-13T22:43:40</date>

extent.value: in 396 containers and 25 flat files, of various sizes.

abstract.value: The records are the archives of the Ethical Cultural Fieldston School, documenting its history from the late 1870s to the early twenty-first century. The records relate to school governance and administration, academics, student life, extracurricular activities, special programming such as camps, parent-teacher association, buildings and facilities, publications, alumni relations, and more.

p.value: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
The collection should be cited as: Ethical Culture Fieldston School records, MS 3042, New-York Historical Society.
Gift of The Ethical Culture Fieldston School, August 2017. Ethical Culture Fieldston also generously provided the funding to support the processing of the archive.

The Ethical Culture Fieldston School is a private independent K-12 school with locations in Manhattan and the Bronx. The school has its origins in the Free Kindergarten, founded in Manhattan by Felix Adler in 1878. Soon after, the school expanded its grade levels and became the Workingman's School in an effort to provide education to the city's underprivileged children. In the 1890s, the school changed its name again to the Ethical Culture School (in reflection of its relationship to the Society for Ethical Culture, also founded by Adler) and began charging tuition. <lb/> 
<lb/>
In 1904, the school moved to a newly constructed building at 33 Central Park West, adjacent to the Society for Ethical Culture. This building housed all grade levels until the opening of a high school at the Fieldston campus in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx in 1928. A second lower school also opened in Fieldston in 1932. In 2007, a new middle school was opened on the Riverdale campus. <lb/> 
<lb/>
For some early years of the school, classes were also conducted at a secondary location called the Branch School. An elementary education department called the Normal School or the Teacher Training Department operated from the 1890s to 1939. At various points in its history, the school has offered several summer and extracurricular programs, including a summer camp in Cooperstown, New York. <lb/> 
<lb/>
The schools have been guided by a Board of Governors, later renamed the Board of Trustees, as well as an overarching administrative department. For much of the twentieth century, this department was called the 3-School Administration, in reference to the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston Lower and Fieldston Upper. Administratively, the school was led by a rector from 1878 to 1942, as well as an educational director (later renamed head of school) from 1928 onward. Individual schools have each been led by a principal.  <lb/> 
<lb/>
Founder Felix Adler served as rector from 1878-1933. He was succeeded by John L. Elliott, founder of the Hudson Guild, who served from 1933-1942. For many years, prominent members of the Society for Ethical Culture could be found acting as chairman of the Board of Governors or the educational director. Financial and administrative ties to the Society for Ethical Culture were formally dissolved in the 1990s. <lb/> 
<lb/>
Long-serving administrators include Educational Directors V.T. Thayer (1928-1948), Victoria Wagner (1954-1968), and Howard Radest (1979-1991); and Fieldston Upper Principal Luther Tate (1941-1966), the namesake of Tate Library.

The Ethical Culture Fieldston School records provide information on the administrative and academic affairs of the school from the 1880s into the twenty-first century. Themes seen throughout include progressive education, independent school administration, curriculum creation, fundraising, and budgeting. The role of ethics, arts, or sports programs in the curriculum, and the school's response to greater societal issues such as wars, racism, poverty, and environmental concerns, are often addressed. <lb/>  <lb/>
Pre-1940 materials in the collection strongly reflect the school's early interest in "manual training" through graphic arts, mechanics, and practical skills curriculum. Later records tend to reflect the school's interest in social progressivism and move toward a college preparatory focus. In addition, the collection contains materials related to extracurricular and summer programs in several record groups, but particularly in "RG 6: Camps and Programs." In addition, "RG 2: Early and Defunct Schools" contains records of the Normal Teacher Training Department. <lb/> 
<lb/>
Themes also seen throughout the collection include: changes in standardization of education and college admissions process (see especially the records of the Eight Year Study in "RG 3: Fieldston School"), the challenges of serving underprivileged communities in an elite institution, and the rise of student activism and a changing adolescent culture beginning in the late 1960s. This last is documented in particular through the protests of the Black and Latino Students Club in 1970, which are discussed in several record groups. <lb/> 
<lb/>
Materials relating to constituent management, particularly parental involvement in school and the maintenance of alumni relations, can be found in several record groups, but especially in "RG 8: Alumni and Alumni Relations" and in "RG 9: Development and Communications." <lb/> 
<lb/>
Information about physical locations at 33 Central Park West and the Fieldston campus in the Bronx can be found in "RG 10: Buildings and Grounds," as well as in "RG 14: Photographs" and in the Board of Governors and administration records in "RG 1: Governance, Administration, and 3-School Affairs." This includes images, architectural plans, and discussion of maintenance, budgets, and space usage.<lb/> 
<lb/>
While the philosophical influence of the Society for Ethical Culture can be seen in administrative and curriculum materials throughout the collection, directly related items consist of Society-produced ephemera, discussion of shared spaces at the Central Park West location, and the financial and legal documents detailing the dissolution of financial ties formalized in 1996. <lb/> 
<lb/>
Correspondence, meeting materials, and administrative documents make up much of the collection, along with ephemera, curriculum materials, student work, and a significant number of photographs. Most materials were created by the 3-School administration, or by the administration of individual schools, with some materials created or collected by teachers or students. Beginning in the 1980s, the Alumni Affairs department played a large role in growing the archival collection by saving contemporary items and collecting donations of older items from alumni and their descendants.  <lb/> 
<lb/>
A very small amount of records relate to photographer Lewis Hine, who taught photography at the Ethical Culture School in the early twentieth century. "RG 14: Photographs" contains copy photographs and copy negatives, along with two photographs marked as possible Hine images. Other mentions of Hine in the collection are later correspondence related to archival inquiries or publicity efforts. Also, while there are very few items directly related to the school's many notable alumni, possible sources of information on individual students include class lists and student rosters from 1891 onward, as well as Fieldston yearbooks and the Fieldston News student newspaper after 1928 found in "RG 11: Print Matter." <lb/> 
<lb/>
More detailed information can be found in the description for each individual Record Group and Series. Researchers should be aware that Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library holds the papers of founder Felix Adler (The Felix Adler papers, 1830-1933), as well as records relating to Adler's successor as rector, John Lovejoy Elliott, in the Hudson Guild records, 1896-1990s.

Record Group 1. Governance, administration, and 3-School affairs (1888-2016; 64.42 linear feet)64.42 Linear feet1888-2016Scope and Contents Note

This record group primarily contains materials related to the governance and administration of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. Nearly all records were created in the twentieth century, with the bulk created between 1930 and 1999. Most records were created by the Board of Governors or the ECFS administration, and cover topics including finances, staffing, fund-raising, physical plant, technology, social issues, educational theory, and long-term planning. Files for head of school positions (rectors, superintendents, and 3-School directors) are also included. Common types of materials found throughout include meeting minutes, correspondence, and reports.

In addition, this record group contains information on faculty and staff, as well as student registration data, from all three schools. Principals' annual reports to the Board of Governors also provide information on individual schools. Other materials related to specific schools can be found in their respective record groups.

Generally, development and public relations materials can be found in Record Group 9: Development and Marketing, but some materials in RG1 relate to these efforts. (For example, discussion of publicity in Board of Governors minutes.)

Arrangement Note

This record group is arranged in six series: Series I. Board of Governors Series II. Rectors and Superintendent Series III. 3-School administration Series IV. Office of the 3-School Director Series V. Admissions and registration Series VI. Faculty and staff

Series I. Board of Governors14.5 Linear feet1903-2004Scope and Contents Note

This series is made up of materials related to the Board of Governors (renamed the Board of Trustees in 1996). Materials include items created by members of Board, as well as items created for use by the Board, such as administrative reports. Records were created between 1903 and 2001, with the bulk of materials in the series created sometime between 1930 and 1990. The majority of items are routine documents, such as meeting minutes and annual status reports, with some correspondence and notes from various chairmen of the Board, as well as long-time Board member Nanette Rothschild.

Arrangement Note

This series is arranged in six subseries: Subseries I.A. Board of Governors: Incorporation, by-laws, minutes, and finances Subseries I.B. Committees Subseries I.C. Reports from the Principals, Directors, and other administrative officers Subseries I.D. Chairman of the Board - Marie S. Neuberger Papers Subseries I.E. Chairman of the Board - Joseph Jablonower papers Subseries I.F. Nanette F. Rothschild Papers

Subseries I.A Board of Governors: Incorporation, by-laws, minutes, and finances1903-2004Scope and Contents Note

This subseries primarily contains minutes for meetings of the Board of Governors (later the Board of Trustees), accompanied by meeting agendas, reports from committees, supplementary meeting materials, and related correspondence. Frequent topics of discussion include finances, enrollment, scholarships, collection of tuition, fundraising, faculty and staff, and buildings and grounds.

While most minutes are concerned with strategy or administrative matters, discussions involving the ethics programs and educational philosophy are included. Issues of racial or economic diversity are also discussed, such as in a 1908 declaration of "non-discrimination by color."

Earlier Board records are more likely to concern individual families or faculty members, or quotidian school business, with discussions moving towards higher level issues throughout the twentieth century. Many files include Executive Committee information (earliest records use the name House Committee). Records from 1981 through 1987 consist of complete mailings sent to Board members. Minutes prior to 1945 are largely facsimiles, not original documents.

Board minutes can also be found in the papers of Chairmen of the Board subseries, or in the Office of the Director series.

Other than minutes, this subseries contains financial documents related to the Board, and some other miscellaneous Board materials.

Arrangement Note

This subseries is arranged by type of document, and then chronologically within each group.

School incorporation, accreditation, and by-laws (3 folders)1903-198411-3Scope and Contents Note

Facsimiles of correspondence regarding incorporation of the school. Facsimile of Certificate of Incorporation of the Society for Ethical Culture with New York State, 1925. Copies of by-laws (printed booklets and photocopies).

Minutes and correspondence of the Board of Governors (27 folders)1903-196414-30Minutes and correspondence of the Board of Governors (26 folders)1965-198721-26Minutes and correspondence of the Board of Governors (20 folders)1988-200431-20Financial documents (4 folders)1906-1993461-4Scope and Contents Note

Includes intermittent correspondence, 1950s budget analysis, and 1990-1991 "Interschool Comparative Study" with financial aid comparisons between other New York schools.

Financial statements (14 folders)1971-2002465-18Scope and Contents Note

Reports from external accountants for the Ethical Culture Schools.

Lists of Board of Governors members (7 folders)1939-2000471-7Scope and Contents Note

Lists of members of the Board of Governors, as well as some lists of guests at meetings and committee assignments.

Miscellaneous documents (12 folders)1909-2004, undated478-19Scope and Contents Note

Miscellaneous statements and correspondence. Examples of specific items include: correspondence of Chairman Frank Karelson, workshop and retreat materials, correspondence of the chair of the Sinaiko Property Committee (1969-1976), Law Committee materials (1974-1979), and a 1909 booklet printed in memorium of Chairman Alfred R. Wolff.

Subseries I.B Committees1936-1999Scope and Contents Note

Types of materials in this subseries include minutes, reports, notes, and a small amount of correspondence, for Board-level committees. Some minutes and reports are found within the overall Board of Governors meeting minutes.

Executive Committee minutes cover similar high-level issues as the overall Board of Governors minutes. External events and issues are often reflected in school agenda items, such as in a 1968 mention of "Anti-War Activities" on campus.

Arrangement Note

This subseries is divided into records of the Executive Committee and records of other committees, then arranged chronologically within each group.

Executive Committee minutes and correspondence (7 folders)1936-1941, 1947-1956321-27Executive Committee minutes and correspondence (31 folders)1956-199641-31Scope and Contents Note

Files include the Ethical Culture Schools – District 9 Cooperative Program Annual Report, 1976-1977.

Committee minutes and reports (8 folders)1949-1999432-39Scope and Contents Note

File include minutes, reports, and notes from the following committees: Director's Search Committee (1970-1979), Education Committee (1983-1990), Enrollment Committee (1949), Committee on Finance and Budget (1954), Finance Committee (1999), Committee on Organization of School (1932).

Committee minutes and reports (8 folders)1945-199051-8Scope and Contents Note

File include minutes, reports, and notes from the following committees: Planning Committees (1982-1990), Principal's Search Committee (1986), Rectorship Committee (1945), Salary Review Committee (1964), and Structure Committees (1973-1978). Some minutes and reports are interfiled with overall Board of Governors meeting minutes.

Subseries I.C Reports from the Principals, Directors, and other administrative officers1934-2000Scope and Contents Note

This subseries consists of reports on administrative and educational issues during the school year at Ethical Cultures Schools. Types of reports vary each year, but nearly all files contain an overall report from the 3-Schools director, along with individual school reports from principals, and sometimes reports from the assistant director, registrar or admissions departments. Many of the reports from the 1930s also have sections written by academic department heads, or reports from the Branch School. Towards the end of the twentieth century, all files begin to include reports from the alumni and development office and the director of admissions and financial aid.

Generally, each principal's report provides a summary of the year's events, departmental issues, new hires, and achievements in teacher and student performance. Reports from directors and assistant directors attempt to confront larger school issues, focusing on budgets, development, faculty and student morale, and facilities. Many reports provide thoughts on ethics issues, parental involvement in the schools, trends in educational theory, technology, and the school's response to larger events and issues, including World War II, the Civil Rights Movement, and the Vietnam War. Occasionally, the administration also makes recommendations or poses questions to the Board.

Earliest reports consist of a lengthy qualitative analysis and personal reflection, with a very small amount of quantitative information (often a college matriculation list). Through the twentieth century, written sections shorten and the amount of quantitative information and data tables increases. 1945 onward, Ethical Culture Schools reports include registration reports with enrollment data. Beginning in the late 1950s, reports of the assistant to the director include a good deal of financial and fundraising information. From the 1960s onward, each year contains a separate report from the registrar's office. Special or ad hoc reports become more common in the second half of the 20th century.

Some files include an accompanying letter from the director, and the 1973 report also includes a letter from the Board in response to the director's report.

Arrangement Note

This subseries is divided into annual and special reports, then arranged chronologically within each group.

Annual reports to the Board of Governors (15 folders)1934-194859-23Scope and Contents Note

The 1939-1940 Fieldston School report appendix includes sample forms, such as report cards.

Annual reports to the Board of Governors (15 folders)1949-196361-15Scope and Contents Note

1960 Fieldston School report includes Report of the Committee on Academic Honesty.

Annual reports to the Board of Governors1963-197771-16Scope and Contents Note

1963-1964 director's report is titled, "After Civil Rights – What?" Civil rights are also discussed in the report of Fieldston Principal Luther Tate that year. During the late 1960s and early 1970s, reports contain considerable discussion of social justice issues and shifts in student behavior and family situations (for example, families with two parents working outside of the home).

Annual reports to the Board of Governors (21 folders)1977-200081-21Scope and Contents Note

Report types become more varied during this time period. Examples include: 1978 reports from the director of the Fieldston day camp and from the coordinator of educational philosophy, a 1979 report on an "Intercultural Exchange Program" between Fieldston and P.S. 98, and a 1996 report titled "Technology at ECF – A Status Report." Long-range planning reports, Ethical Fieldston Fund information, and Parent & Teacher's Association reports are also seen. Computers and new technology are frequently discussed.

Special reports to the Board of Governors (2 folders)1963-1996, undated822-23Scope and Contents Note

One-off reports and memos to the board. Includes reports and memos from Luther Tate, Howard Radest, and Frank Karelson.

Subseries I.D Chairman of the Board - Marie S. Neuberger Papers1934-1989Scope and Contents Note

Materials of Marie S. Neuberger, including those created during her tenure as chairman of the Board from 1955-1964.

Arrangement Note

In this subseries, correspondence and Board of Governors records are arranged chronologically, while subject files are arranged alphabetically.

Files involving finances (1934-1982), fundraising (1954-1964), real estate (1964-1967), school policies (1960-1980), and administrative organization (1967-1981).

Subseries I.E Chairman of the Board - Joseph Jablonower papers1936-1952Scope and Contents Note

Subject files A-S (26 folders)1941-19501119-43Scope and Contents Note

Mostly correspondence, with some ephemera, news clippings, reports, and meeting minutes. Significant subjects include budgets, facilities and properties, the Parent & Teacher's Association, school programs and camps, and staffing (including discussions of salaries and of the rectorship, and the Educational Director search in 1947-1948).

Subject files S-T (7 folders)1941-1950121-7Subseries I.F Nanette F. Rothschild Papers1921-1987Scope and Contents Note

Unless otherwise noted, materials generally consist of meeting minutes, documents, notes, news clippings, ephemera, and correspondence. Files contain a small amount of Herbert M. Rothschild materials as well.

This subseries follows the earlier arrangement created by the Ethical Culture School archives.

Board of Governors (29 folders)1933-1975128-36Scope and Contents Note

Materials related to Rothchild's work with the Board of Governors. Topics include by-laws, administrative organization, staff and faculty policies, school finances, year-round programs, and admissions diversity. Also includes copies of 1930s financial reports, and handbooks for parents and teachers, 1950-1966.

Directors and Fieldston principals (13 folders)1947-19781237-49Scope and Contents Note

Material relating to criteria for search committees, positions, and Fieldston's administrative structure.

History, philosophy, and future of the Schools (11 folders)1938 - 19751319-29Scope and Contents Note

Essays, articles, and addresses on the history of the School, its purpose (especially in regard to ethics), and goals for its future. Notes and letters by Rothschild.

Fieldston (13 folders)1924-19791250-62Scope and Contents Note

Addresses (including graduation speeches), reports, and publications on Fieldston. Topics include the direction and philosophy of the Schools, policies, curriculum, and student-faculty relations. Includes copies of the Fieldston School Evaluation Reports for 1971 and 1975.

Elementary and three-school curriculum concerns (6 folders)1921-19731263-68Scope and Contents Note

Series III. 3-School administration3.5 Linear feet1928-2012Scope and Contents Note

This series contains records of 3-School administrators (primarily related to 3-School educational directors), committees, and evaluations of the Schools. Additional records from specific eras of the 3-School director's office can be found in the following series.

Arrangement Note

This series is arranged in three subseries: Subseries III.A. Educational Directors Subseries III.B. 3-School committees Subseries III.C. Evaluations of the Schools

Series IV. Office of the 3-School Director23 Linear feet1937-1999Scope and Contents Note

Materials created in the second half of the twentieth century by the 3-School director and others working in the 3-School administration, including assistants to the director, assistant directors, business managers, and public relations staff. Records have largely been left in their original order, and are grouped into subseries according to original sets of chronologically-related materials. Original file titles have been retained wherever possible.

Series VI. Faculty and staff6.5 Linear feet1901-2006Scope and Contents Note

This series contains records of both individual employees (3-School and individual schools) as well as records addressing issues and policies that affect faculty and staff as a whole.

Arrangement Note

This series is arranged in two subseries: Subseries VI.A Faculty and administration personnel files Subseries VI.B Faculty matters

Subseries VI.A Faculty and administration filescirca 1901-1994Scope and Contents Note

This subseries consists of individual files for faculty and staff. For the majority of individuals, materials consist of one folder relating to their employment and work at the Ethical Culture Schools. Nearly all materials in the series were created between 1920 and 1950. (The small amount of items created in the 1970s through the 1990s are mostly obituaries or memorial items for past faculty.) The series is arranged alphabetically by last name.

Files of teachers and principals are most commonly found, but the series also contains several files for psychologists and guidance counselors, librarians, medical staff (especially dieticians and nurses), facilities staff, secretaries, and business managers. Both 3-School staff and staff from individual schools are included.

Correspondence, both with and regarding the individual, makes up the bulk of the series. Letters typically discuss administrative matters, classroom issues, contracts, salaries, requests for supplies, and facilities issues. The majority of correspondence is internal to the Schools, along with instances of correspondence with vendors or colleagues at other educational institutions. Many correspondence items concern employment, including inquiries into work at the Ethical Culture Schools, requests by Fieldston for references or other information about a prospective employee, or requests for references by other schools. There are some examples of personal correspondence, such as invitations, or notes keeping in touch with past employees.

Other than correspondence, files contain curriculum items, schedules, summer contact information cards, news clippings, ephemera, and classroom materials (syllabi, bibliographies). Obituaries, memorial service programs and other tribute materials are found throughout. There is some discussion of specific students, before 1950.

The personnel files for some individuals do contain substantive materials about the work of their department. In particular, the folders of Henry Kelly (14 folders, 1902-1939), August Klock (7 folders, 1923-1940) contain a good deal of information about the biology department, including the report "The Science Course at Fieldston," 1930. The following files contain information about each department, mostly during the 1930s and early 1940s: Margaret Koch, history; William Kurtz, physical education and athletic programs; Ethel Murphy, math; Alberta Newton, Greek and Latin. The two files of Arthur Richards contain information on the printing shop in the 1920s. Other departments represented include English, ethics, chemistry, fine arts, French, and German.

This subseries is arranged alphabetically by last name.

Miscellaneous (7 folders)1937-20175915-21Record Group 2. Early and defunct schools (1879-1957; 13.17 linear feet)13.17 Linear feet1879-1957Scope and Contents

This record group includes materials for the Ethical Culture School and its programs prior to the opening of the Fieldston campus in 1928. This includes records for the earlier iteration of the school, The Workingman's School, and its evolution to Ethical Culture Schools. The record group also contains records for discontinued early programs: the Summer Play School, the Open Air Department, and the Normal Department for Teacher Training.

Types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, reports, student work, photographs, and news clippings. Board records and administrative records from this era can be found in Record Group 1, and additional ephemera can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter.

Arrangement

This record group is organized into four series: Series I. Defunct schools Series II. Ethical Culture Schools Series III. Normal Teacher Training Department Series IV. Normal School student records (RESTRICTED)

Series I. Defunct schools1 Linear feet1883-1927Scope and Contents

This series includes records for early schools and programs that are no longer in existence: the Workingman's School, the Open Air School, and the Summer Play School. (The Branch School was also in operation during this era, but collection does not contain any related records.) These early records mostly consist of ephemera and reports from teachers and principals, along with four scrapbooks compiled by Summer Play School leader Mabel Towne Burnham.

The Open Air Department conducted classes on the roof of the Central Park West Building from the 1910s through the 1920s. The Summer Play School was founded in partnership with the New York Federation for Child Study (later the Child Study Association of America) in 1919, providing summer activities and meals for underprivileged children at the Ethical Culture School building on Central Park West.

Series IV. (RESTRICTED) Normal School student records7 Linear feet1913-1978Scope and Contents

This sub-series consists of individual records for Normal Department teacher trainees from the class of 1919 through the class of 1939. Records date from 1919 to 1978, but the majority of records were created during the years students were enrolled in the program, or soon after.

Nearly all files contain an application for admission (often including letters of recommendation or high school transcripts), acceptance letters, observation reports on teaching sessions, and other documents on performance in the program. Many materials, including transcripts and recommendations sent to prospective employers, relate to student job searches after graduation. Many files also contain applications for scholarships, class schedules, verifications of medical examination or vaccination, marriage announcements and invitations, news clippings (mostly regarding marriages), and photographs. Files for the class of 1933 through 1939 include a small photograph of each student; other photographs are noted at the files level.

Correspondence topics include admission, performance in program, tuition, requests for references, and events in the lives former students who are keeping in touch with faculty. Records for the classes of 1940 and 1941, along with additional records for the class of 1939, are unprocessed.

Arrangement

Files are arranged chronologically by graduation year, then alphabetically by student last name.

Conditions Governing Access

The Normal School student records are closed to general access until 2040. To request permission to access these files, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted to anyone before 2040 without the explicit, written permission of the COO.

Record Group 3. Fieldston School (1925-2012; 18.75 linear feet)18.75 Linear feet1925-2012Scope and Contents

This record group includes materials for the Fieldston School, the secondary school often referred to as the Upper School and later divided into Fieldston Middle and Fieldston Upper. Overall, the series provides information on the administrative and educational work of faculty and staff, as well as the academic and extracurricular life of students in Form I through Form VI. Types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, meeting materials, reports, student work, photographs, and news clippings.

The papers of principals and other senior administrators, including long-time principal Luther Tate can be found in this record group. Evaluations of the schools are also included, most notably the "Eight-Year Study, a 1930s multi-school study on secondary education and college preparation. This record group also contains materials on Fieldston-specific faculty matters and school policies.

Academic programs are represented with annual department reports from the 1930s through 1980s, assorted departmental records, curriculum materials, and some examples of student work. Programs, newsletters, news clippings, and other ephemera cover student athletics, performances (including dance, drama, and music) and student clubs and organizations.

Copies of school newspapers and literary journals, along with additional ephemera relating to school activities, can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter. Records related to the construction of the Fieldston campus and Tate Library can be found in Record Group 10, Buildings and grounds. Class directories and individual faculty information can be found in Record Group 1. Prior to 1928, secondary education was conducted at the Ethical Culture School in Manhattan, so those earlier records can be found in Record Group 2, Early and defunct schools.

Arrangement

This record group is organized into three series: Series I. Administrative affairs Series II. Academic affairs Series III. Student life

Record Group 5. Fieldston Lower (1933-2012; 6.5 linear feet)6.5 Linear feet1933-2012Scope and Contents

This record group contains materials related to the Fieldston Lower School, the elementary school on the Fieldston campus. The bulk of materials are related to curriculum and student activities, or the day-to-day activities of the faculty and administration. Substantial information can be found in the 1985 report on Fieldston Lower by the New York Association of Independent Schools, and in annual department reports. Types of items include correspondence, ephemera, reports, teacher instruction materials, along with art and other projects created by students.

Arrangement

This record group is organized into two series: Series I. Administrative affairs Series II. Academic affairs and student life

This record group contains materials relating to summer camps and other programs created and managed by the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. Notably, this includes the Ethical Culture School Camp in Cooperstown, New York, in existence from the 1920s to the 1970s. Records for day camps held on school grounds are also included, along with records for summer programs designed to assist public school students with high school or college preparation. Common types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, reports, and news clippings. Additional information on extracurricular activities and after-school programs can be found in Record Groups 3, 4 and 5. Items relating to the Summer Play School (founded 1919) can be found in Record Group 2.

Scrapbook1958-1959343Record Group 8. Alumni and alumni-relations (1891-2015; 28.5 linear feet)28.5 Linear feet1891-2015Scope and Contents

This record group contains materials related to the alumni of Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. This includes records of the Alumni Association, internal alumni-relations programs, and the Director of Alumni Affairs, as well as materials on the work and lives of former students. Archival materials donated by alumni are also found here. Correspondence, meeting materials, news clippings, and ephemera make up most of the record group, along with some photographs and examples of student work. Records date from the 1890s through the 2010s, but the majority of items were created between 1970 and 2010. Additional alumni fund-raising and alumni-relations records can be found in Record Group 9, Development and Communications and in files of the administration in Record Group 1. Copies of alumni directories and other ephemera can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter.

Arrangement

This record group is arranged in three series: Series I: Alumni Association Series II: Office of Alumni Affairs Series III: Alumni materials (Arrangement is based on previous processing efforts by the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, with additions by the archivist.)

This series contains records from the Alumni Association, an alumni-led group. Meeting materials for the Association and the Alumni Executive Board make up much of the series, which also contains ephemera, lists of officers and members, and correspondence. Frequent topics include reunions and other social functions, fund-raising, and the relationship of the Alumni Association to the school.

Subseries III.C Mabel Towne Burnham1892-1970Scope and Contents

Mabel Towne Burnham, long-time Ethical Culture School employee, served in roles including Director of the Summer Play School in the 1920s, and Registrar in the 1930s. The series primarily contains scrapbooks she made during her years at Ethical Culture, along with clippings and ephemera intended for or removed from scrapbooks. It also includes some personal items (such as a diary and account books), and notebooks and printed matter from Essex High School and the Salem Normal School. The bulk of materials were created between 1900 and 1945.

Duplicate print matter collected by Burnham1909-1964203Record Group 9. Development and communications (1885-2009; 17.25 linear feet)17.25 Linear feet1885-2009Scope and Contents

Record Group 9 consists of materials related to development and communications efforts for the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Subject matter includes development appeals, the management of gifts and funds, school programs, public relations, and strategic planning. It contains a small amount of materials from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, but the vast majority of records were created after the establishment a dedicated program for fund-raising and publicity in the 1950s. Types of materials include correspondence, reports, meeting materials, press releases, ephemera, and news clippings. Files related to the celebration and publicity of the school's various anniversary celebrations can also be found in this record group. Records related to fund-raising for the construction of new buildings, especially Tate Library, can be found in Record Group 10, Buildings and grounds. Administrative and Board of Governors materials in Record Group 1 also often involve development or public relations efforts.

Arrangement

Series II. Fund-raising and publicity, 1950s-1970s12.25 Linear feet1950-1983Scope and Contents

Series II contains records from the administrative office for fund-raising and publicity from the 1950s through the 1970s. This era saw the establishment of the Ethical Fieldston Fund and the Development Committee, with regular appeals to alumni and parents, and simultaneously, the creation of the Public Relations Working Committee and the publication of the 1954 report, "A Public Relations Program for the Ethical Culture Schools." Fund-raising materials include copies of appeals, committee and meeting materials, reports on campaigns and funds, and correspondence. Publicity efforts, often managed by the same staff, are represented in committee materials, correspondence, and a good deal of press releases, which were created frequently in this era. Background materials on various school programs, as well as some general school administrative records can also be found in this record group. Related records can be found in Record Group 1, Subseries IV.C., the records of the editorial and publicity assistant to Director Victoria Wagner.

Arrangement

This series is arranged in four subseries: Subseries II.A: Ethical Fieldston Fund and appeals Subseries II.B: Projects, campaigns, and events Subseries II.C: Administrative and foundational records Subseries II.D: Public relations

Record Group 10. Buildings and grounds (1882-2005; 26.65 linear feet)26.65 Linear feet1882-2005Scope and Contents Note

The Buildings and grounds series primarily contains materials related to the construction of Ethical Culture School buildings, both in Manhattan and the Bronx. A large portion of the record group is devoted to the planning and construction of Tate Library on the Fieldston campus in the 1960s and 1970s. Types of materials include correspondence, meeting materials, ephemera, government documents, news clippings, press releases, photographs, and architectural drawings.

Records related to fundraising efforts, especially for the construction of the Midtown Ethical Culture School building during the 1920s and the Tate Library during the 1960s, are also included. Architectural drawings and diagrams are generally oversize. For the most part, architectural images appear to have been produced for display or general information, not for use during construction.

Arrangement Note

This record group is organized in three series: Series I. 33 Central Park West Series II. Fieldston buildings and properties Series III. Tate Library

Record Group 13. Ethics Department and the Society for Ethical Culture (1901-1999; 7.5 linear feet)7.5 Linear feet1901-1999Scope and Contents

This record group contains materials related to the Society for Ethical Culture, its shared philosophies with the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, and ethics program curriculum. The Society for Ethical Culture was established in 1876 by Felix Adler, who founded the Workingman's School two years later. In 1895, the Society took governance of the newly named Ethical Culture School. Since 1996, the Society and School have been officially separate organizations. Based on the Society's teaching, the ethics program was intended to guide students both in their personal lives and their places in the greater world. It was described in 1984 as "based on the personal, social, and intellectual development of our students and responding to the moral issues that they meet in experiences." Types of materials include correspondence, reports, ephemera (produced both by the Society and ECFS), legal documents, meeting minutes, teacher guides, and curriculum materials. Records were created throughout the 20th century, but the bulk of materials are dated between the 1970s and 1990s.

Arrangement

This record group is arranged in two series: Series I. The Society for Ethical Culture Series II. Ethics Department

Series I. Society for Ethical Culture2.5 Linear feet1901-1999Scope and Contents

Records in this series involve the relationship between the Society for Ethical Culture and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Subjects include the influence of Society teachings on the School's philosophy, the use of shared spaces in the Central Park West building, the administration of shared funds, and the formal financial separation of the two organizations in the 1990s. It also includes papers of Algernon Black, an ECFS alumni and long-time leader of the Society, as well as early 1990s records related to the separation, from the office of Head of School Jeanne Amster.

Series II. Ethics program5 Linear feet1901-1993Scope and Contents

This series contains records of the Ethics program at all grade levels of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. The Ethics curriculum is built on humanistic teachings, with subjects including interpersonal relationships, mental and physical health, current events, history, religion, and moral theory. There is a focus on teaching through examples in myths, folklore, and fiction throughout the program. As Educational Director Dr. V.T. Thayer wrote of the program's goals in 1936, "One, that children be led through the school to discover and to develop their unique possibilities of mind and character; and second that their growth should proceed at all times in sensitive response to fundamental aspects of the society in which they live and move and have their being." The majority of records were created between 1979 and 1990, during the tenure of Head of School Howard Radest. (Radest also managed the Ethics program in this era, and was involved in the leadership of the Society for Ethical Culture.) It also includes printed copies of stories and texts from throughout the 20th century.

Record Group 14. Photographs (1882-2016; 62.97 linear feet)62.97 Linear feet1882-2016Scope and Contents

This record group contains photographs and photographic materials. Photographic prints make up most of the record group, which also contains negatives, slides, and discs with digital images. Image content includes students, staff, faculty, alumni, buildings, arts programs, athletic programs, and events. Both amateur and professional photographs are included. Many photographs were taken by faculty and staff, with some donated by families and alumni. Dates of creation range from 1887 to 2016, with the bulk of materials created in the second half of the twentieth-century. A small amount of photographs can also be found in other record groups, where noted.

Arrangement

This record group is arranged in five series: Series I. Ethical Culture Fieldston photo archive Series II. Scrapbooks and albums Series III. Photographs after 1980 Series IV. Communications collections Series V. Oversize materials and special formats

Record Group 15. (RESTRICTED) Audiovisual (1950s-2008, undated; 26.42 linear feet)26.42 Linear feet1950s-2008, undatedScope and Contents

The Audiovisual record group contains audio or moving visual recordings. Types of materials include film reels, audio tape, cassette tapes, VHS and other video cassettes, and vinyl records. The title or identifier for each individual item is listed in this inventory. The majority of content has been captured by amateurs, such as school employees, with some professional recordings. For all materials in this record group, audio and visual content has been identified solely by labels or other written description accompanying objects (not by playback).

Arrangement

This record group is arranged in three series: Series I. Film Series II. VHS Series III. Audio recordings

Conditions Governing Use

Note that the audiovisual material in this record group is restricted due to its fragility and because the New-York Historical Society lacks the necessary playback equipment. Patrons wishing to view or listen to any of the material in this record group should contact the curator of manuscripts at manuscripts @nyhistory.org

Record Group 18. (RESTRICTED) Student records (circa 1910-1940; 70 linear feet)74 Linear feetcirca 1910-1940Scope and Contents

Some student records from the early decades of the twentieth century are held in the collection, dating through about 1940. These include student files from the midtown school and the Fieldston campus. This record group does not include student records from the Normal School (last graduating class was in 1941), which are found in Record Group 2. These student records are all closed to general access until 2040. New-York Historical Society generally holds no student records for graduating classes from 1940 and later, though a very few random files from the early 1940s appear to have been interfiled with the earlier files. The files include grades, qualitative evaluations, permission slips, correspondence, notes on college acceptances, etc. The files include some documents from years after the student left ECFS such as requests for transcripts, clippings (regarding marriages and the like), and other individual alumni matters.

There are three sets of records: files for graduating classes up to 1936, files for graduating classes of 1937-1939, and index cards of records for students. Each set of files are in alphabetical order by student surname. The index cards were originally labeled as "withdrawn students through 1936," but there are cards for students through 1940 (and a very few from the early 1940s) and there are cards for students who graduated from tthe schools.

The index card files are clearly incomplete as seen by the obvious gaps in the alphabetical sequence. It is not known how complete the other two sets of files are.

To request permission to access any student historical records, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted without the explicit, written permission of the COO.

Arrangement

The record group is arranged such that the three sets of files (to 1936, 1937 to about 1940, and index cards) are boxed in their original order as found. The files are unprocessed and remain in their original folders, which are fragile, as are some of the documents in the files.

The index cards were rehoused from their original deteriorated boxes, but the original labels were retained, principally to help highlight the gaps in the records. The number of cards per student ranges widely, from a single card to perhaps dozens. Many, though not all, of these multiple card sets were originally held together by rubber bands, which have all dried out and crumbled apart. Consequently, care needs to be taken in using the cards to ensure that they do not get mixed up. However, many of the cards were already found mixed up during re-boxing in 2019; the archivist attempted to ensure that the order of names in the boxes were generally correct, but users should not expect the cards to be in perfect sequence within a particular student's cards or across student cards. This will be especially so for students with identical names, students with cards that referred to them by different names (e.g., Robert and Bob), and cards with variant surname spellings for the same student (e.g., Cohen/Cohn/Cone).

Conditions Governing Access

The record group is closed to general access until 2040. To request permission to access any student historical records, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted to anyone before 2040 without the explicit, written permission of Fieldston's COO.
